Answer: That’s a long ways away, so it’s hard to say what the market will look like 10 years from now. But given the way things are going, deep learning is becoming a bigger field. Now you asked about 3 things, big data, machine learning, and deep learning. I wouldn’t think of these as three distinct subfields. Big data simply describes a subset of data science that has at least 2 of the “3 v’s” (Velocity, volume, variety). If a large amount of data is coming in very quickly, it’s considered big data. As is a small amount of data with a high degree of variance that is coming in quickly. It’s sort of aThat’s a long ways away, so it’s hard to say what the market will look like 10 years from now. But given the way things are going, deep learning is becoming a bigger field. Now you asked about 3 things, big data, machine learning, and deep learning. I wouldn’t think of these as three distinct subfields. Big data simply describes a subset of data science that has at least 2 of the “3 v’s” (Velocity, volume, variety). If a large amount of data is coming in very quickly, it’s considered big data. As is a small amount of data with a high degree of variance that is coming in quickly. It’s sort of a misnomer, I realize. Machine learning and deep learning, on the other hand, are methods of analysis performed on data (big data or otherwise). So to answer your question properly, I’ll say that data is always getting “bigger”. We’re producing more and more of it and we’re developing ways of getting it to you faster (sometimes out of necessity, not convenience.) So yes, big data will be highly regarded in 10 years, but that’s like saying, “Math will be important 10 years from now.” It’s apparent, but it’s broad. AI may take a huge leap forward and make deep learning a trivial process. But as with any other tech field, you just have to stay on top of new developments. If something replaces deep learning, then learn that new thing. Data science will be around forever, it’s just a question of what form it will take.

Answer: I doubt either of them will look much like they do today. I think we're going to see more pipelines, more topology/geometry in algorithm design, and new algorithms that we can't even imagine today. We'll also probably start to see a focus on data quality rather than quantity as other companies begin to use machine learning. It's also possible that we will have quantum computers by then, which will change how we design and implement algorithms.

Answer: Big tech has been dominating the big data and machine learning landscape the last decade or so, but other sectors have jumped on the data bandwagon in large numbers in the last couple of years.Large companies in traditional sectors like banking, retail, energy, manufacturing and many others are almost invariably making data a central part of their strategies these days by building data science teams and hiring top talent.Big tech is now playing the role of technology enabler by selling their cloud platforms to the large players in other sectors. Platforms like Azure, AWS, IBM Watson and GoogleBig tech has been dominating the big data and machine learning landscape the last decade or so, but other sectors have jumped on the data bandwagon in large numbers in the last couple of years.Large companies in traditional sectors like banking, retail, energy, manufacturing and many others are almost invariably making data a central part of their strategies these days by building data science teams and hiring top talent.Big tech is now playing the role of technology enabler by selling their cloud platforms to the large players in other sectors. Platforms like Azure, AWS, IBM Watson and Google Cloud are now mature enough that they can help customers generate real value from data science.This is pretty much the situation as of mid-2017, but things are changing rapidly. I suspect many smaller companies will also enter the fray in the years ahead.

Answer: You don’t advance technology as a monolith. Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falsely believes nuclear energy to be more dangerous than fossil fuels due to decades of propaganda by idiots.So no. Germany is not the most technologically advanced country. It could be pretty close, but there are major elements of society who dedicate themselves to making sure that Germany uses inferior technology that kills more people, damages the environment more, costs more money, and will cause the total collapse of Earth’s biosphere due to a runaway greenhouse effect. Mostly in the Green Party. Because radiation from nuclear accidents is apparently scarier than way more people dying of regular pollution constantly and the total annihilation of all life on Earth as the oceans boil away.
